new_src_summary: In a lighthearted and conversational tone, the author, Tim Urban, shares humorous anecdotes about his struggles with procrastination during his academic career, particularly as a government major in college. Despite his intentions to manage time effectively, he repeatedly found himself completing assignments in a rushed manner at the last minute, contrary to his vision of a balanced workload. This pattern culminated in his senior thesis, a 90-page project that ideally should have been spread out over a year. Urban initially planned a gradual increase in effort, but this strategy failed, leaving him with only a few weeks to finish. Remarkably, he managed to write the entire thesis in 72 hours, including two consecutive all-nighters, and submitted it just before the deadline. Although he expected his thesis to be poorly received, he humorously imagines a scenario where it is praised as exceptional. Today, Urban is a writer and blogger at Wait But Why, where he explores the psychology of procrastination. Driven by his personal experiences, he hypothesizes that procrastinators' brains may be structurally different from those of non-procrastinators. To investigate this, he organized MRI scans of his own brain and that of a non-procrastinator, intending to share the findings with his audience. Throughout the narrative, Urban maintains a humorous and self-deprecating style, highlighting the common struggle with procrastination while also delving into its psychological underpinnings.

new_src_summary: In a humorous and self-reflective tone, Tim Urban, the writer and blogger at Wait But Why, shares his personal experiences with procrastination during his academic years, illustrating the universal struggle through amusing anecdotes. Despite his intentions to manage time effectively as a government major in college, Urban found himself repeatedly completing assignments at the last minute, even writing his entire 90-page senior thesis in just 72 hours with two consecutive all-nighters. Inspired by these experiences, Urban delves into the psychology behind procrastination, proposing that procrastinators' brains might fundamentally differ from non-procrastinators'. By comparing MRI scans of his own brain with that of a non-procrastinator, he humorously elaborates on the concept of an Instant Gratification Monkey residing in the procrastinator's brain alongside the Rational Decision-Maker. The Monkey takes control when productivity is required, steering the procrastinator towards immediate pleasures and distractions, leaving essential tasks unattended. This behavior, advantageous in ancient times for survival, is ill-suited for today's society, leading to procrastination and avoidance of tasks, resulting in the individual spending excessive time in the "Dark Playground" of unearned leisure activities, accompanied by negative emotions. Procrastinators often rely on the "Panic Monster," an internal mechanism that motivates action when faced with impending deadlines or potential negative outcomes, creating an engaging and insightful discussion on the psychological underpinnings of procrastination within the context of human evolution and modern society.
new_tgt_summary: Tim Urban, un ancien étudiant en sciences politiques devenu blogueur-écrivain, est célèbre pour son exploration du comportement des procrastinateurs, domaine dans lequel il a une expérience personnelle significative. Durant ses études, malgré sa compréhension du défi d'écrire un mémoire de 90 pages, qui demande normalement une année de préparation, Urban reportait son travail jusqu'à la dernière minute, finissant même son mémoire entier en seulement 72 heures avant la date limite. Il attribue cette tendance à une prétendue différence structurelle dans le cerveau des procrastinateurs, qui abritent un 'Singe de Plaisir Immédiat' aux côtés du 'Preneur de Décisions Rationnel' existant dans tous les cerveaux. Ce 'Singe', recherchant le confort instantané, peut prendre le dessus sur le 'Preneur de Décisions Rationnel', provoquant des distractions prolongées. Cette dynamique se joue spécifiquement dans le "Parc Sombre du Plaisir", une zone de distractions non productives. Cependant, le 'Monstre de la Panique' intervient lorsque les échéances approchent ou que des conséquences potentiellement graves sont en vue, forçant ainsi l'individu à quitter ce parc de distractions et à accomplir des tâches essentielles. Pour étayer sa théorie, Urban a même soumis son propre cerveau et celui d'une personne non procrastinateuse à une IRM.

new_src_summary: In a lighthearted and introspective narrative, Tim Urban, the writer and blogger at Wait But Why, uses his personal experiences with procrastination to explore the psychological underpinnings of this universal struggle. Through amusing anecdotes from his academic years, including the completion of his 90-page senior thesis in a mere 72 hours with two back-to-back all-nighters, Urban illustrates the dichotomy between his intentions to manage time efficiently as a government major and the reality of succumbing to last-minute efforts. Drawing parallels between his brain and that of a non-procrastinator, Urban humorously introduces the concept of an Instant Gratification Monkey cohabiting with the Rational Decision-Maker in the procrastinator's mind. The Monkey seizes control when productivity is needed, steering the procrastinator toward immediate pleasures and distractions, while the Panic Monster emerges as an internal mechanism that spurs action only when faced with impending deadlines or potential negative consequences. This engaging discussion is further exemplified through Urban's experience preparing for a TED Talk, where the Monkey suggests unrelated activities until the Panic Monster's awakening forces a retreat, allowing the Rational Decision-Maker to take charge and commence work. This scenario encapsulates the procrastinator's system, marked by avoidance and eleventh-hour productivity, providing insightful commentary on human evolution, modern society, and the behavioral science of procrastination in a casual, relatable, and self-reflective tone.
new_tgt_summary: Tim Urban, ancien étudiant en sciences politiques reconverti en blogueur-écrivain, est reconnu pour son analyse perspicace du comportement des procrastinateurs, domaine où il a une expertise personnelle notable. Durant ses études, Urban a souvent repoussé la rédaction de son mémoire de 90 pages jusqu'à la dernière minute, le terminant une fois en seulement 72 heures avant la date butoir. Il explique cette habitude par une supposée particularité structurale du cerveau des procrastinateurs, qui hébergerait un 'Singe de Plaisir Immédiat' outre le 'Preneur de Décisions Rationnel'. Ce 'Singe' cherche constamment le confort instantané, déplaçant le 'Preneur de Décisions Rationnel' et entraînant des distractions prolongées, particulièrement dans le "Parc Sombre du Plaisir", une zone de distractions non productives. Cependant, le 'Monstre de la Panique' surgit quand les délais sont proches ou face à des conséquences potentiellement graves, forçant l'individu à sortir de ce parc distrayant et à accomplir des tâches cruciales. Urban a même validé sa théorie par une IRM comparée avec un non-procrastinateur. Lorsqu'il a accepté d'intervenir lors d'une conférence TED, un rêve pour lui, cette dynamique s'est révélée à nouveau : le 'Preneur de Décisions Rationnel' a ressenti une angoisse anticipée tandis que le 'Singe' suggérait des distractions comme l'utilisation de Google Earth. Alors que la date de la conférence approchait, le 'Monstre de la Panique' a fait son apparition, incitant le 'Singe' à se retirer et permettant au 'Preneur de Décisions Rationnel' de se concentrer sur la préparation de la conférence. Cette expérience, partagée sur son blog quelques années plus tôt, illustre parfaitement la dynamique interne des procrastinateurs, génératrice de comportements de procrastination extrêmes mais finalement productifs.

new_src_summary: In a reflective, insightful, and empathetic narrative, Tim Urban, the writer and blogger at Wait But Why, delves into the psychological aspects of procrastination using his personal experiences and a lighthearted yet introspective style. Urban shares humorous anecdotes from his academic years, such as completing a 90-page senior thesis in just 72 hours with two consecutive all-nighters, to illustrate the contrast between his intentions to manage time efficiently and the reality of succumbing to last-minute efforts. He humorously introduces the concept of an Instant Gratification Monkey coexisting with the Rational Decision-Maker in the procrastinator's mind, seizing control when productivity is needed and steering the procrastinator toward immediate pleasures and distractions. The Panic Monster emerges as an internal mechanism that spurs action only when faced with impending deadlines or potential negative consequences. Urban's experience preparing for a TED Talk further exemplifies this scenario, encapsulating the procrastinator's system marked by avoidance and eleventh-hour productivity. After receiving an overwhelming response to his post on procrastination, with thousands of emails from individuals worldwide, including nurses, bankers, painters, engineers, and PhD students, Urban highlights the contrast between the lighthearted tone of the post and the serious consequences of procrastination on people's lives. He distinguishes between two types of procrastination: one involving tasks with deadlines, which triggers the Panic Monster, and another affecting long-term goals and personal relationships without clear deadlines, leading to extended periods of inaction. This second type, less visible and less discussed, can cause significant long-term unhappiness and regrets, affecting careers, health, and relationships. The emails suggest that many people suffer from this quiet and private form of procrastination, shedding light on the behavioral science of procrastination and its impact on human evolution and modern society.
new_tgt_summary: Tim Urban, un ancien étudiant en sciences politiques devenu blogueur-écrivain, est reconnu pour son analyse profonde du comportement des procrastinateurs, un sujet qu'il maîtrise bien, ayant souvent repoussé la rédaction de son mémoire de 90 pages jusqu'à la dernière minute durant ses études. Urban attribue ce comportement à une prétendue structure cérébrale unique chez les procrastinateurs, caractérisée par un 'Singe de Plaisir Immédiat' et un 'Preneur de Décisions Rationnel'. Le 'Singe' recherche constamment le confort immédiat, écartant le 'Preneur de Décisions Rationnel', entraînant ainsi des distractions prolongées, surtout dans le "Parc Sombre du Plaisir". Cependant, le 'Monstre de la Panique' apparaît lorsque les délais sont imminents ou face à des conséquences potentiellement graves, forçant l'individu à agir. Cette dynamique a été illustrée lors de sa préparation pour une conférence TED, une expérience qu'il a partagée sur son blog. Suite à cela, il a reçu des milliers d'e-mails de personnes de toutes professions, partageant des frustrations similaires liées à la procrastination. Urban distingue deux types de procrastination: celle déclenchée par des délais et une autre sans délais, typiquement rencontrée dans les carrières d'auto-entrepreneurs ou les domaines non professionnels. Cette dernière, sans le déclencheur du 'Monstre de la Panique', conduit à une procrastination indéfinie, source d'un grand malheur et de regrets pour beaucoup, expliquant pourquoi ils se retrouvent dans des situations difficiles.
